Cultivating rice is their main way of earning income and they always hire the neighbors water buffalo to help their farm work. They now want to own their own buffalo and are requesting a loan to purchase two water buffalo. The loan will help their family by reducing their farming expenses.

loans.use: to purchase two water buffalo

loans.name: Sang

texts.en:
Sang P., age 26, is a mother of two and lives with her husband in Prey Chor district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Sang P. works growing seasonal rice and breeding pigs to achieve her standard of living,  Her sows breeding cycle is about six to seven months, when all the pigs are big enough to go to market. The number of piglets she can afford to raise is about five to six pigs per cycle. With her daily business activity, P. can earn $3/day of income.

Her husband, Mr Pham Pang, age 29, works as a motorcycle-taxi driver, transporting passengers to different locations in her community and can typically earn about $3 each day.

Sang would like to request a loan to purchase a rice mill to use for grinding.

loans.use: To purchase a rice mill to use for grinding

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun E., 46, and her husband, Mr.  Sophal Ung, 45, who live along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1986 and have six children, three sons who are in school and three daughters who are garment factory workers.  As well, Saroeun’s mother resides with them.

Saroeun has been selling fruit for two years, buying them in her village for resale at a market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a house builder for 17 years.  Saroeun is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase mangoes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes for resale.

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha Y. (pictured with her son), 46, and her husband, Mr. Sros Soeung, 48, who live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, were married in 1993 and have four children: two sons who assist their parents in growing watermelons and two daughters, one married and living outside the family home and the other a garment factory worker.

Chantha has been selling desserts for four years, buying the ingredients to cook and selling the finished products at Chbar Amporv market. Her husband grows watermelons. Chantha is now requesting a loan of $300 to purchase a water-pumping machine for her husband’s farm.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump machine to use for growing watermelons.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng S. A., age 24, lives in Prey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She owns a business in Phom Penh city selling a variety of fruits at the market. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver. 
Together, this couple earns about $8 of income a day. She rents a fruit stand from someone near the market and pays them a monthly fee.
S. A. is requesting a loan to rent another stand to expand her fruit business. With this business expansion, she believes she would increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To rent a second stand to expand her fruit sales

loans.name: Bin

texts.en:
Bin C., 34, is a mother of three children and works with her husband growing rice and some kinds of vegetables such as cucumber, lettuce and tomato, making collectively about $7 per day of income.

One of her children is employed at a garment factory and the rest are students.

For her monthly expenses, Bin C. spends on average $30 on food, $2 on utilities, $15 on her children’s tuition fees and $3 on transportation.

Bin C. has recently asked for a loan to open a grocery business for one of her children so that she can generate additional profit for the household

loans.use: To open a grocery store for one of her children to increase her household income

loans.name: Sophai

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophai N., 29, and her husband, Mr. Hun Hor, 33, residents of a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 2001 and have two daughters.  Sophai’s mother also lives with them.

Sophai has been a silk weaver for 11 years, a skill learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then resells them in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for two years, and the couple hopes that their businesses will allow their children to pursue higher education in the future.  

Sophai is now requesting a loan of $600 to purchase silk material for weaving and construction crane materials for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving and construction crane materials for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Hout

texts.en:
Hout S., 25, lives in Kompong Tom Province. She raises pigs near her house as well as being a rice trader, purchasing rice to store and re-sell to make a profit. She can earn an average of US$ 3 per day and has been running her businesses since 2007.

Hout S. is married and is a good mother to her young daughter while her husband is a carving-wood seller. To grow her business and earn additional revenue, S. needs to borrow money to purchase rice to store and then sell for a profit. The loan will help her increase her income to cover a little more of the family's living expenses. (She and her lovely child are pictured.)

loans.use: to purchase rice to store and re-sell

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is divorced and has one child. She sells curtains and accessories at Image Market in Beregovo city. Her monthly gross income is 20,000 UAH; the profit is about 5,000 UAH per month.

Svetlana started this business 8 years ago. She was lucky to choose this type of goods to sell, because she had very little competition then and even now the competition is low. This gives Svetlana a good opportunity to make her living. Svetlana is a kind and hard-working person. She treats her clients well and has a desire to develop her business even more.

Svetlana would like to receive a loan of 1,000 USD to increase her inventory. Additional capital would allow her to offer a better assortment of curtains and serve even more clients.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mr. Sim M., 58, and his wife, Mrs. Sarim Hoem, 53, who live in a small village along National Road Number Two about 13 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1970 and have two children, a son and a daughter. One is married and lives outside the family home, and the other child has full time employment. They also have two grandchildren living with them.

Sim has been a motor remoque taxi driver for ten years. A remoque taxi is a motorbike with a trailer at the back, allowing Sim to transport people and goods from his village to Phnom Penh. His wife maintains their home. Sim is now requesting a loan of $500 to buy a new trailer to replace the old one for his taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer for his motor taxi business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom P., 30, and her husband, Mr. Sary Phoung, 35, were married in 1997 and have two children, a son and a daughter, both attending the local school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mom has been selling Cambodian cakes and fruits for ten years, buying them from the Prek Phnao market for resale in the local school. Her husband has been a teacher since 1998. Mom is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for use in the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for use in the family.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthy T., 45, and her husband, Mr. Chheng Lach, 46, who live along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1982 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family house; three daughters are garment factory workers, two children attend school and the other daughter is still young.

Chanthy has been selling vegetables for three years. She buys them from Derm Kor market for re-sale at Koki market near her village. Her husband has been a chef for 20 years. He cooks for wedding ceremonies and other special occasions.

Chanthy is applying for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to carry vegetables for sale.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer to carry vegetables for sale

loans.name: Khy

texts.en: Khy S. is 35 years old and lives in Kompong Tom Province where she runs a little store selling Khmer Noodles. With the business, she can earn about US$ 2 a day. She stared this business in 2006. She is the mother of three children, all of whom are teenagers. Her husband, Mr. Kroch Chin, is 33. He is a domestic ox trader, buying cows from far away  to raise and re-sell at a profit. He faces difficulty with his transportation and often hires a motorcycle from a neighbor to ride to work. He hopes to own a motorcycle, hence he talked with his wife and they decided to request a loan to purchase a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.use: to purchase a second-hand motorcycle

loans.name: Sokhun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhun M., 46, and her husband, Mr. Pov Kong, 31, married in 1996 and have four children; two sons and two daughters. Three of their children attend school and the other one is still young. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sokhun and her husband have been growing lotus for twelve years and have been growing rice since they were young. She is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 500 to repair their motorized hand tiller and purchase fertilizer for farming.

loans.use: To repair a motorized hand tiller and purchase fertilizer for farming

loans.name: Silun

texts.en:
Mrs. Silun M., 28, and her husband, Mr. M. Mer, 35 who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2001 and have two daughters. One of them attends school and the other daughter is still young.

Silun has been a tailor for three years. Her husband has been raising pigs for three years as well. Silun is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to build a pigpen for her husband's pigs and to purchase rice for re-sale.

loans.use: To build a pigpen for her husband's pigs and to purchase rice for re-sale

loans.name: Phal

texts.en:
Phal P., 29, is a motorcycle taxi driver. He provides his service for passengers going from village to village in the area of his community, and he can earn around US$ 3 each day to buy food for his family. He is married to Keo Sokhey who is a grocery seller. She sells items such as cooked food and sweets for kids; she has experience in this business for a long time. Keo Sokhey now has four children, all of whom are single; one of her daughters is employed as a worker in Malaysia.

P. is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase grocery inventory for his wife to sell and piglets to raise. The family lives in Kompong Tom Province. (P.'s wife is pictured, because he was not available that day.)

loans.use: to purchase inventory grocery

loans.name: Ponlork

texts.en:
Mr. Ponlork N., 35, and his wife, Mrs. Sopheak Khorn, 34 live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1994 and have four children: three sons who are learning Khmer traditional music and one young daughter.

Ponlork has been a musician for nine years. He wants to create another business producing rice wine to get extra income for his family. His wife has been selling fish and raising pigs for three years. Ponlork also assists his wife in raising pigs when he has free time. He is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase raw materials for producing rice wine.

loans.use: To purchase materials for producing rice wine.

loans.name: Amon

texts.en: Amon J. is a Tanzanian businessman. He runs a shop at Vituka Ward. He sells a variety of items including cereals. He purchases from wholesale shops in Kariakoo business center and other things directly from the producers. The income generated by his business is used to pay his children's school fees and meet the family's daily demands. He wants to purchase more items to meet his customers' demand. He needs a loan of Tshs 800,000.

loans.use: To expand his  business selling cereals, etc.

loans.name: Samneang

texts.en:
Mr. Samneang P., 36, and his wife, Mrs. Sreysros Chhoung, 31, live in a small village along National Road Number Two about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1996 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. One of them attends school and the other two children are still young.

Samneang has been a motortaxi driver for five years. His wife has been a garment factory worker since 2001. Samneang lacks the money to purchase a new motorbike and trailer to drive "Tuk Tuk". Therefore, he is asking for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to drive motor taxi (Tuk Tuk).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer to drive motortaxi (Tuk Tuk).

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun S., age 45, and her husband, Mr. Yorn Yin, age 44, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1990 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Three of their children attend school, one child is a weaver and the youngest child is still very young and stays at home.

Saroeun has been a silk weaver for 17 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a house builder and rice grower for the last 10 years. He is a horse cart driver as well. 

Saroeun is requesting a loan of 300USD to purchase silk material for her weaving business and part of the loan for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase materials for weaving and for growing rice.

loans.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Mr. Kosal K., age 40, and his wife, Mrs. Sakun Tit, age 36, live along the No. 1 national road , about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1989 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Both of the children attend school.

Kosal and his wife have been farming for four years. They grow gourds, green beans, and lotus on their farm in the village. They sell their produce to a middleman in the village.  Kosal is applying for a loan of $500 to grow lotus.

loans.use: To purchase materials for growing lotus.

loans.name: Chinda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chinda P., age 25, and her husband, Mr. Socheat Chab, age 28, were married in 2003 and have two children: one son and one daughter. The children are still very young. The family lives along the No. 1 national road, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Chinda has been selling fruit for five years. She buys them in her village and then resells them at the Derm Kor market. Her husband has been a mason for one year. They dream that someday their children will become doctors.

Chinda is applying for a loan of $500 to purchase one motorbike to transport her fruits to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport fruits to sell.

loans.name: Nhean

texts.en: Nhean S. is 22 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province. She earns a living by raising pigs in a stall next to her house. She will raise two lots of pigs per year and sells them to the slaughterer every six months. She has been earning an income of approximately $4 a day, since 2006. She is married with one son who is a minor and still under her care. Her husband is a farmer and also a wood cutter. To expand the business and earn more revenue, S. is applying for a loan to buy additional piglets to raise and a buffalo to use in her husband business.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Fada Mohammad

texts.en:
Fada M. is 32 years old and lives in distract 12, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with two children. Fada works as a carpenter and has a small shop. He requires a small loan for his shop to increase his inventory and make his business larger

He requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani over a term of 12 months and wants to expand and progress in his business. He needs to increase his shops stock of wood to have material available to meet his customers needs.

He is happy that this process of making small loans is available in Afghanistan and wants to thank kiva and all the lenders around world.

loans.use: To purchase wood for carpentry shop

loans.name: Husina

texts.en: Husina H. is a Tanzanian woman who owns a water well at Vituka in Dar Es Salaam. She supplies water to customers for domestic use purposes in Vituka. People in Dar Es Salaam have limited access to water, so businesses like Husina's are very important. Husina wants to increase water supplies for her customers by drilling more wells. She is requesting  a loan of  Tsh. 600,000.

loans.use: To expand business (drill a new well)

loans.name: Isaiah

texts.en: Isaiah A. M. is married and has 2 children. He has received no formal education. Isaiah sells and repairs electrical gadgets at Aboom in Cape coast, which he has been doing since 2003. Isaiah uses his income to pay his children's school fees, the family's utility bills, and other expenses. Isaiah will use the loan to expand his business by purchasing additional electrical items for resale. He plans to invest the extra profit in his children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of electrical items for resale

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet B. is married and has 3 children. She has received highschool education. Since 2003, Janet has been selling groceries like biscuits, canned products, and others items in Intarbeton, Cape Coast. Janet uses her income to support her husband in paying utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. She plans to use the loan to purchase additional groceries to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the extra profit, Janet will be able to supplement her husband's savings to acquire a piece of land for building their family house.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries for sale

loans.name: Hamidu

texts.en: Hamidu H. C. is an enterprising Tanzanian businessman. He runs a shop at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam city center. He sells a variety of items. He purchases the items from various wholesale shops at the Kariakoo business center and stores around Buguruni. His business plan is to run a wholesale store. Income derived from the business is used to capitalize the business and meet his family's daily needs. He requests a loan of Tshs 600,000 to increase the inventory of his store.

loans.use: Increase store inventory and expand business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is married and has one child. She has received junior high education. Since 2005, Mary has been earning income baking bread in large quantities for distribution and sale at Cape Coast. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more flour, margarine, sugar, and other baking ingredients to enable her to increase the bread production volume. She hopes to use the extra profit to help her husband pay for the education of their child.

loans.use: Purchase of flour, margarine, sugar, and other ingredients for a bread-baking business

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en: Shirley A. is married and has 3 children. She has received highschool education. Shirley owns a hairdressing salon at Ola in Cape Coast, which she opened in 2003. Shirley uses her income to pay her children's school fees, the family's utility bills, and other expenses. She will use the loan to purchase different kinds of hair products to meet the demand of her costumers. Shirley plans to invest the additional profit in her children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of various hair products

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina M. is single and has no children. She has received senior high education and, since 2003, has been earning income sewing and selling fabrics. A seamstress by profession, Augustina sells different kinds of fabrics and both male and female clothing at Intarbeton, Cape Coast. She uses her income for paying utility bills and covering various personal expenses. Her loan will be used to buy additional fabrics and sewing materials. She hopes to use the extra profit to reinvest in the business to increase its capital base.

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics and other sewing materials

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is married and has a child. She has received junior high education. Since 2004, she has been selling groceries like biscuits, canned products, and other items at Intarbeton, Cape Coast. Esther uses her income to support her husband in paying utility bills and covering other basic expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to buy additional groceries to meet the increasing demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the extra profit to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries for sale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria A. is single. She has received schooling through junior high and is a seamstress by profession. Since 2001, Gloria has been selling a variety of fabrics at Aboom in Cape coast. She uses her income to pay her children's school fees, the family's utility bills, and other expenses. Gloria will use the loan to purchase additional fabrics and sewing materials. She will reinvest the extra profit in her business to increase its capital base.

loans.use: Purchase of fabrics and sewing materials

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward M. is single and has no children. He has received schooling through senior high. Since 1995, Edward has been selling both male and female footwear at Kotokoraba, Cape Coast. Edward uses his income to pay the utility bills and other personal expenses. He will use the loan to purchase additional footwear to meat the demand of his costumers. Edward plans to save the extra profit to be able to build a house before he starts a family.

loans.use: Purchase of footwear for sale

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta B. is single and has no children. She has received schooling through senior high. Since 2005, Benedicta has been selling groceries like biscuits, canned products, and other items at Intarbeton in Cape Coast. She uses her income to support her parents in paying utility bills and other basic expenses. Benedicta will use the loan to purchase additional groceries to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She will save the extra profit to be able to build a house before she starts a family.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries for sale

loans.name: Racila

texts.en: Răcila T. has 32 years old and is active in farming. T. is a member of a credit bank group for the village of Carabetovca. She lives in Carabestovca village, Basarabeasca district, Moldova. Racila's family is actively involved in cereal farming.  The family has two farms and they have farmed this land since 1994. The farms are heavily mechanized though there is still much manual work. This is her second loan with Microinvest. The first loan for 5000 lEI, to purchase fertilizer, seeds and loan payments, was repaid May 24, 2007.  The loan, now requested is required to purchase farm chemicals and mechanical equipment parts.

loans.use: To purchase the chemicals and mechanical parts

loans.name: Catana

texts.en:
Catana T. is 56 years old with a plesent personality and good health. She is the leader of a loan group with Microinvest in Carabetovca village. She lives in Carabetovca village, Basarabeasca district, Moldova. Her main business is agriculture. Catana's family owns  5.2 hectaire of arable land which they have worked since 2000. The farm is highly mechanized but Catana still has to do a lot of manual work.  She also works as part of the local staff of Microinvest in the Carabetovca village loan group. 

Her farm is located in Carabetovca village Basarabeasca district and the business was launched in 2000. This is the third loan from Microinvest: the first, in the amount of 5000 lei, was repaid on 24,05,20007, and was used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and service payments , the second, in the amount 5000 lei, was repaid on 24,12,2007, and was used to purchase seeds and to pay equipment servicing. 

The requested  loan is required to purchase fertilizers, seeds and engineering services payments.

loans.use: purchase fertilizers, seeds and to pay for engineering services.

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
La señorita  Zoila es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen D. Cancharani” D. la provincia D. Puno, en el departamento D. Puno. Tiene 57 años D. edad, es soltera y madre D. 5 hijos. Con su primer préstamo D. S/. 300 compró golosinas para venderlas. Tiene casi 7 años  trabajando con el banco. Nos cuenta que vive con 2 hijos actualmente y a parte D. vender golosina venD. quesanas.
Con este préstamo D. S/.2000 que pagará en 6 cuotas comprará productos D. campaña naviD.ña.
Zoila desea continuar trabajando para tener una tienda D. ropa.
texts.en:
Ms. Zoila is a member of the “Virgen D. Cancharani” microfinance institute in the province and department of Puno. She is a 57-year-old single mother with 5 children. With her first loan of 300.00 PEN, she purchased candy for resale. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost 7 years. She states that she currently lives with two of her children. AsiD. from selling candy, she also sells bulrush mats.

With this 2,000.00 PEN loan, which she will repay in 6 monthly installments, she will purchase seasonal items.

Zoila hopes to continue working so that she can open up her own clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase holiday items

loans.name: Yovana

texts.es:
La señorita Yovana es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de Cancharani” de la provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno. Tiene 32 años de edad, es conviviente y madre de 1 hijo. Con su primer préstamo de S/. 300 compró ropa y dulces para venderlos. Tiene casi 3 años  trabajando con el banco. Nos cuenta que es docente en Macusani de lunes a viernes.
Con este préstamo de S/.1200 que pagará en  6 cuotas comprará ropa y zapatillas para la campaña navideña.
Yovana desea continuar trabajando para construir y tener una tienda de golosinas.
texts.en:
Ms. Yovana is a member of the “Virgen de Cancharani” microfinance institute in the province and department of Puno. She is 32 years old and has a live-in partner and a son. With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased clothing and candy for resale. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost 3 years. She states that she teaches in Macusani from Monday through Friday.

With this 1,200.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 6 monthly installments, she will purchase clothing and shoes for the holiday season.

Yovana hopes to keep working so that she can build her own candy store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing and shoes for the holiday season

loans.name: Pilar

texts.es:
La señora  Pilar es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Amigas” de la provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno. Tiene 45 años de edad, es casada  y  madre de 3 hijos. Con su primer  préstamo de S/. 300 compró ropa para venderla. Tiene casi 2 años trabajando con el banco. Pilar nos cuenta que todos sus hijos están estudiando actualmente; ella trabaja actualmente en el restaurante del colegio militar
Con este préstamo de S/. 1500 que pagará en 4 cuotas comprará  una cocina más grande y mayor cantidad de vajilla, mesas largas.
Pilar desea continuar trabajando para llegar a ser propietaria de una cafetería en el centro de la ciudad.
texts.en:
Ms. Pilar is a member of the “Las Amigas” microfinance institute in the province and department of Puno. She is a 45-year-old married mother of 3 children. With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased clothing for resale. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost 2 years. Pilar states that all her children are currently in school; right now, she is working at a restaurant in a military school.

With this 1,500.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 4 monthly installments, she will purchase a bigger stove, more dishware and long tables.

Pilar hopes to continue working so that she can one day own a cafe downtown.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bigger stove, more dishware and long tables

loans.name: Catana

texts.en: Catana N. has 58 years old, active and in good health.He is a member of the Carabetovca village credit group. He lives in Carabetovca village, Basarabeasca district. Catana's main occupation is farming. He and his family have farmed  5,2 hectaires of arable land for cereal crops since 2000. Much of the work is done by mechanized equipment, but he must still do a lot of hard physical work. The business is registered as a farm operation, with the business location as Carabetovca village Basarabeasca district. The business was launched in 2000. This is Catana's second loan with Microinvest; the first, in the amount of 5000 lei was repaid on 11.05.07. The loan now requested is required to purchase farm chemicals and mechanical parts.

loans.use: purchase of farm chemicals and mechanical parts.

loans.name: Mery Angelica

texts.es:
La señorita Mery es socia del Banco Comunal “Dante Nava” de la provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno. Tiene 40 años de edad, es soltera  y  madre de 3 hijos. Con su primer  préstamo de S/. 300 compró papelería para su librería  y madera para confeccionar ataúdes  y venderlos en su funeraria. Tiene casi 8 años trabajando con el banco. Mery nos cuenta que compro una capilla ardiente
Con este préstamo de S/. 2000 que pagará en 4 cuotas comprará  madera para almacenar en su taller y más material para su librería.
Mery desea continuar trabajando para comprar un lote y construir su casa propia.
texts.en:
Ms. Mery is a member of the “Dante Nava” microfinance institute in the province and department of Puno. She is a 40-year-old single mother with 3 children. With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased stationery for her bookstore and lumber to make coffins for her funeral parlor. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost 8 years. Mery states that she purchased a funeral chapel. With this 2,000.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 4 monthly installments, she will purchase lumber to store it in her carpenter’s workshop and materials for her bookstore.

Mery wishes to continue working so that she can buy a plot of land and build her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase lumber and materials for her bookstore

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señorita Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen de Cancharani” de la provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno. Tiene 43 años de edad, es soltera y madre de 3 hijos. Con su primer préstamo de S/. 300 compró insumos para su negocio de comidas preparadas. Tiene casi 6 años  trabajando con el banco. Nos cuenta que es guía de turismo y que trabaja también el obispado.
Con este préstamo de S/.1500 que pagará en 4 cuotas mejorará su cocina e implementos y mejorar su servicio
Mercedes desea continuar trabajando apoyar a sus hijos a ser profesionales.
texts.en:
Ms. Mercedes is a member of the “Virgen de Cancharani” microfinance institute in the province and department of Puno. She is a 43-year-old single mother with 3 children. With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she purchased ingredients for her food preparation business. She has been working with the microfinance institute for almost 6 years. She states that she is also a tourist guide and works in the bishopric. With this 1,500 PEN loan, which she will repay in 4 monthly installments, she will improve her kitchen, her tools and her service.

Mercedes hopes to continue working in order to support her children in becoming professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improve kitchen, tools and service

loans.name: Kalambène Group

texts.fr:
http://sem-fund.org/oussouye.php 
Pour une deuxième fois, nous venons solliciter auprès de Kiva un prêt pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus. Nous avions dans le passé reçu un prêt qui nous a beaucoup aidé à voir comment gerer un microcrédit et maintenant nous voulons faires des investissements pour faire un travail durable comme par exemple faire de la teinture de tissus et la vente du produit fini dans les hotels et boutiques de notre écovillage. Avec les gains de notre premiers prêt, nous avons satisfait aux besoins de nos familles respectives:(ecole, santé) et aussi nous sommes parvenues à nous prendre en charge nous même. Cette fois-ci le prêt vas nous permettre de travailler sur une plus large échelle et va impliquer plusieurs personnes( environs douze); Nous savons que nous pouvons compter sur Kiva car c'est le seul partenaire qui nous prête de l'argent sans condition et vite fait.
texts.en:
This will be the second loan that we have solicited from Kiva. The loan will be used to support activities that will generate revenue. We have in the past, received a loan that assisted us greatly and showed us how to manage a micro-loan. Now,we would like to make investments, along with hard work to produce for example; the dying of cloth and the sale of the finished product to the hotels and boutiques within the Ecovillage Fund group. With the profits made from our first loan we were able to satisfy the needs of our individual families ( school, health) as well as meet our responsibilities. This second loan will allow us to work on a larger scale and will involve several more persons (about twelve). We know that we can count on Kiva as they are a partner who can quickly lend funds without conditions.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cloth, dyes and other items used in the dying process

loans.name: Abou

texts.fr: Abou S. est un frigoriste, il habite le populaire Grand Dakar. Ce marié et pére de 3 enfants arrive grâce à son activité à entretenir sa famille et à réaliser des bénéfices. Il sollicite ce prêt pour augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
Abou S. works in the refrigeration field. He lives in the working-class district of Grand Dakar. A married man and the father of three, he manages to support his family through his work and to realize some profit. He is requesting this loan to increase his income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Refrigration

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
La Señora Santos es una socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Emprendedoras”, vive en la región  San Martín provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, se dedica a la venta de productos de pan llevar como plátanos, menestras, yuca verduras, Mani, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado central de la ciudad,  a donde acuden diariamente a comprar sus clientes que son los visitantes del mercado.

Con este préstamo de S/.  2 000.00 nuevos soles, que pagara en 6  meses, comprará plátanos en racimos, yuca en sacos, frijoles en sacos de diferentes variedades así como también en la compra de peluches que en esta época del año tiene buena acogida por las fiestas de fin de año. 

Santos tiene  58 años,  ella es madre de 9 hijos, ya todos son independientes, ahora vive con su esposo y uno de sus hijas quien le apoya en su negocio y acompaña a sus padres, esta agradecida por el apoyo brindado por Manuela Ramos que le permite crecer en su negocio a ella así como también a las demás mujeres trabajadoras.
texts.en:
Ms. Santos is a member of the “Mujeres Emprendedoras” (Enterprising Women) microfinance institute. She lives in the San Martin region of the province and district of Moyobamba. She sells produce such as plantains, legumes, cassava, vegetables and peanuts. Her business is located in the city’s central market, where her customers go everyday. With this 2,000.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will purchase plantains by the bunch, sacks of cassava, sacks of an assorted variety of beans, and plush toys that are in demand this season because of the year-end festivities.

Santos is a 58-year-old mother with 9 children who are all independent. She now lives with her husband and one of her daughters, who helps her with the business. She is grateful for the support she has received from Manuela Ramos, which allows not only her business to grow, but also those of the other working women.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase plantains, cassava, beans and plush toys

loans.name: Mansata

texts.fr:
Mansata M. a une cantine au marché de Grand Dakar. Elle vend du tissus et de la mercerie pour soutenir son époux dans la prise en charge de la fammille.
Cette brave mére de famille sollicite ce crédit pour renforcer son commerce et engranger davantage de revenus.
texts.en:
Mansata M. has a shop at the Grand Dakar marketplace. She sells cloth and sewing supplies to support her husband with regard to family responsibilities. This good and honest woman is requesting a loan to boost her commerce and to accumulate more income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Teodora

texts.es:
La señora Teodora, socia del  B.C. “Santa Ana”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia y distrito de Moyabamba, ella tiene su salón de belleza  en su propia casa, en la que se dedica a cortar  y teñir  el cabello de damas, caballeros y niños, asimismo da servicio de manicure, pedicure y vende productos de belleza de la línea LIFE, actividad para la que esta capacitada, por lo que su trabajo es bien reconocida en la ciudad. 

Con este préstamo de  S/. 2 500.00, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará materiales que utiliza diariamente como: tintes en diferentes colores y marcas por docenas, shampoo, cremas para cuerpo y manos por docenas, y productos para el cuidado del cabello de la línea LIFE, asimismo parte del dinero lo invierte en la construcción de departamentos que piensa alquilarlos mas adelante una vez terminados. 

La señora Teodora tiene 47  años, vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijo quienes aun dependen de ella, anhela terminar de construir los departamentos así como mantener su salón bien arreglado.
texts.en:
Ms. Teodora, a member of the “Santa Ana” microfinance institute, lives in the San Martin Region of the province and district of Moyabamba. She has her own beauty salon in her house. She does haircuts and dyes for men, women and children. She also provides manicures and pedicures, as well as sells LIFE beauty products. She is qualified for this business, which is why she is well-known in the city.

With this 2,500.00 PEN loan, which will be repaid in 6 monthly installments, she will purchase supplies that she uses daily, such as: hair dye in different shades and brands by the dozen, shampoo, hand and body lotion by the dozen, and LIFE hair care products. She will also invest some of the loan in building apartments that she plans on renting out once they have been finished.

Ms. Teodora is 47 years old, and lives with her husband and 4 dependent children. She wishes to finish construction of the apartments and have a well-kept beauty salon.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty supplies and invest in construction of apartments

loans.name: Las Americas Group

texts.en:
The Las Ameritas Village Bank has twelve members and is beginning its second loan cycle. During the group’s first cycle, members were given training and educational sessions, which they are now putting into practice in their daily lives.  The group members are involved in a variety of different businesses; they sell condiments, accessories, bread, dry goods, sweets, clothing and fruit, and also prepare natural juices. Some sell from home or in local markets, while others sell in the street or make home deliveries.  The group members are requesting different loan amounts, like 300, 600 or 1,050 soles. The group as a whole is requesting a total of 8,400 soles. The loans will be used to buy cookies, caramels, hot peppers, cumin, bananas, papayas, bread, t-shirts and pants.  Group members dream of improving and expanding their businesses, of owning their own homes or their own stores, and that their children will graduate will professional degrees.

 Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Banco Comunal Las Américas inicia su segundo ciclo con 12 socias, en el primer ciclo recibieron diferentes temas de capacitación que ahora están poniendo en practica en su vida diaria. 
 Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de condimentos, pasamanería, panes, abarrotes, golosinas, preparación de jugos naturales, ropa, frutas. Sus ventas los realizan en algunos mercados, en sus domicilios, reparten a domicilio, ambulantemente. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de préstamos, algunos montos son de 300 soles, 600 soles, 1050 soles  haciendo un total de 8,400 soles de préstamos en el Banco Comunal. 
Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra de galletas, caramelos, ají, comino, plátano, papaya, panes, polos, pantalones. 
Los sueños de las socias son mejorar y ampliar su negocio, tener casa propia, tener un local para sus negocios y sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy cookies, caramels, hot peppers, cumin, bananas, papayas, bread, t-shirts and pants

loans.name: Gotitas De Amor Group

texts.en:
The Gotitas D. Amor (“Little Drops of Love”) Village Bank is a new group that is just starting out with fifteen members, who after weeks of training are very happy to get started.  The group members are involved in a variety of businesses: they sell cell phones, bread, cakes, vegetables, firewood, plastics, clothing for children and adults, grains, and catalog cosmetics. The group members sell from home, on delivery, on the street and in several of the city’s markets.  They are each requesting different loan amounts, like 300, 600 or 750 soles. The group is requesting a total of 5,700 soles.  Group members will use their loans to buy carrots, onions, firewood, bags, t-shirts, sweaters, blouses, wheat, barley and corn.  The group members dream of owning their own homes, of expanding their businesses, of providing their children with all the best and a good education. 

 Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Banco Comunal Gotitas D. Amor es un Banco Nuevo que recién inicia con 15 socias, quienes después D. semanas D. capacitación inician con mucha alegría. 
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. celulares, panes, pasteles, verduras, leñas, plásticos, ropa para adultos y niños, cereales, cosméticos por catálogos Sus ventas los realizan en sus domicilios, reparten a domicilio, ambulantemente y en algunos mercados D. la ciudad. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 600 soles, 750 soles  haciendo un total D. 5,700 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.
Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra D. zanahoria, cebolla, leña, bolsas, polos, chompas, blusas, trigo, cebada, maíz. 
Los sueños D. las socias son tener casa propia, ampliar sus negocios, brindar a sus hijos todo lo mejor, buena educación.

loans.use: Buy carrots, onions, firewood, bags, t-shirts, sweaters, blouses, wheat, barley and corn

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina A. is forty-six years old. She is married and a mother of three children. She has all of her children in school. She has been a local manufacturer of palm oil for two years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits; the palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil, which is produced first. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil.

Georgina produces and supplies her product to food vendors to use in preparing meals. She even treks to the villages to purchase finished goods elsewhere when demand becomes very high. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of palm nuts, gallons to store the oil, and an electric milling machine in order to increase her efficiency and produce in larger quantities. Georgina believes this will help expand her business and raise more income to support her husband, provide food for her family, and finance her children’s education.

Georgina belongs to the community group called Nyame Nhyira, meaning God Blessing Trust Group. Her picture was taking during their group meeting. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and act as peer pressure to repay them.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine.

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia S. is a 57 year old mother of eight children. Five of the children are independent and the rest are still in school. She has been a local manufacturer of soap and smoked fish seller for seven years in the market place of Babiani where she lives.

To prepare the local soap, Afia combines materials like palm oil, soda powder, cocoa pods, and coconut oil. She is not able to produce in large quantities for lack of funds. She wants to take advantage of the loan facility to buy more raw materials and processing equipment to scale up production and increase her quantity of smoked fish.

Afia sells at the surrounding villages during their market days. She hopes to raise improved income to support her children's education. She belongs to the community group called Nyame Nhyira, meaning God Blessing Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and act as peer pressure to repay the loans.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make soap (like palm oil, soda powder, cocoa pods and coconut oil) and smoked fish to sell.

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr: Moustapha S. est un commerçant ambulant qui habite Kandialang au Sud de Ziguinchor. Avec sa bicyclette ce brave homme satisfait à la demande sociale de sa petite famille. Il demande ce prêt pour acheter davantage de marchandises et réaliser un peu plus de bénéfices.
texts.en:
Moustapha S. is an itinerant merchant who lives in the Kandialang district located on the southside of Ziguinchor. With his bicycle, this good and honest man is meeting the demands of his small family. He is asking for this loan to buy more merchandise and to realize a little more profit.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia D. is forty-one years old. She is married with two children. At the moment, one has completed senior high school. She has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and palm kernel oil for eight years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits and the palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil, which is produced first. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil. Palm kernel is used to prepare many local dishes.

Her production is on a small scale because she has inadequate capital to buy machines for the processing. She wants to use this loan to buy more palm nuts to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her husband, provide food, and finance her children’s education.

Felicia belongs to a community group called Nyame Nhyira, meaning God Blessing Trust Group. Her picture was taking during their group meeting. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and act as peer pressure to repay the loans. She said she would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more palm nuts fruits and a small milling machine.

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
La señora Marina, socia del B. C “Mujeres Emprendedoras”,  vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, se dedica a la venta de  abarrotes en general y bebidas gasificadas, su negocio esta ubicado en su casa a donde acuden a diario sus clientes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2 000.00  nuevos soles que pagará en 06 meses comprará  productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar en saco, detergentes de diferentes marcas, conservas, leche en cajas, artículos de higiene personal y demás productos que requiere para surtir su negocio y satisface las necesidades de sus clientes.

La señora Marina,  tiene 42 años de edad,  vive con sus 3 hijos y su esposo quien se dedica a trabajos eventuales, esta agradecida con el apoyo brindado por que le permite crecer en su negocio, su meta es crecer en su negocio y comprar su casa.
texts.en:
Marina, a member of the “Enterprising Women” cooperative bank, lives in the San Martín region of the Moyobamba district. She dedicates herself to selling groceries and soft drinks. Her business is located in her own home, where her customers go every day. With this loan of 2,000.00 Peruvian soles, which she will repay in six months, she will purchase basic products such as rice, sugar by the sack, various brand detergents, canned goods, boxed milk, and personal hygiene products that she needs to supply her business and satisfy her customers’ needs. Marina is 42 years old and lives with her three children, as well as her husband who dedicates himself to temporary jobs. She is thankful for the support provided, as it allows her to grow her business. Her goals are to expand her enterprise and to purchase her home.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic necessities such as rice, sugar by the sack, various brand detergents, canned goods, milk, personal hygiene products, and also products to supply her store and satisfy her customers' needs.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha N. is 55 years old. She is married with eight children. At the moment, two are still in the senior high school. Martha has been a local manufacturer of palm oil and palm kernel for seven years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits and the palm kernel is a by-product of palm oil, which is produced first. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil, which is used to prepare many local dishes.

Martha's production is on a small scale due to inadequate capital to buy machines for the processing. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm nuts to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. Martha believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her husband, provide food, and finance her children’s education.

Martha belongs to a community group called Nyame Nhyira, meaning God Blessing Trust Group. Her picture was taking during their group meeting. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and act as peer pressure to repay the loan. She said she would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more palm nuts fruits and gallons to store her finish goods.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia K. is thirty-five year old trader. She is married with three children who are currently attending school through the help of government free compulsory education. It is her daily dream to provide quality education for her children to give them better future life.

Felicia owns and operates a grocery shop with items like rice, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, and evaporated milk. She wants to use this loan to buy cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks and cooking oil to increase her stock of goods. With increased stock of different variety, she hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of her children. She hope to pay the loan in due time because she believes the loan would boost her business growth. Her picture was taking when she was visited at her business site.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her grocery shop, like cartons of evaporated milk, bags of rice, canned foods and drinks, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida M. is a divorced mother of one child, who is currently attending the final year of high school. Vida is a 37 year old trader. She trades in lace and cloth materials, which most women use to sew dresses. Lace material is also very useful in room and office decorations.

Because she lacks adequate working capital, Vida buys small amounts of lace and cloth materials and sells them in the market place of Babiani, where she lives with her family. She believes this loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. She wants to purchase bulk quantities of lace materials and clothing. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her child with quality education.

Vida belongs to the community group called Ephesians Trust group. She says your support would enable her to realize her dream. Her picture was taking when she was visited at the market where she sells.

loans.use: To purchase bulk quantities of lace materials and textiles.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort O. is forty-three years old. She is a married mother of six children. Three of her children have completed high school while three are still in the basic school. Comfort lives with her husband, a farmer, and her children in a mining/farming community called Bibiani in the Western Region. Her husband cultivates palm nuts in the community in which they live.

Comfort works hard to help her husband provide for the family. She sells beef in the local market square. Comfort also roasts some of the meat and sells it in the form of kebab. She says children in her community also come to collect for hawking on commission.

Comfort orders the meat from Burkina Faso where cost is quite economical. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to order beef in bulk. She belongs to a Trust Bank group called Nyame Nhyira (God’s Blessings). The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy beef in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is a 36 year old trader. She is a single mother with two children, who are both currently in school. She is a very resourceful single mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family.

Grace supports her kids by selling used clothing, which has a very big market share in Ghana as brand new cloths are very expensive for the economically active poor. She has being in this business for the past eight years. Selling used clothing has created a market for many women.

She travels to a nearby city called Kumasi to purchase her stock of goods. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She normally concentrates on bed sheets and used towels sales. She believes this loan would help her save for her children’s future and also to rent a store to trade. Her records can be identified in group called Adehye, meaning Royals. She is very much convinced that your help would enable make her dream come through.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Emmanuella

texts.en:
Emmanuella O. is 37 years old. She is married and has four children. She says with the help of God that all her children attend school. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk, and biscuits in her neighborhood of Babiani, where she lives.

With this loan, Emmanuella wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, and boxes of biscuits to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children in school.

Emmanuella has being selling grocery products for eight years now and she belongs to a Trust group called Adehye, which means Royals Trust Group. She was so enthused when her business was assessed and she was offered business advice. Emmanuella says she would be very grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her grocery store, such as cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water, and boxes of biscuit.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. is thirty-two years old and married with three sons, who are all in elementary school. She lives with the family in a mining and farming dominated town called Bibiani in the Western Region. Felicia’s husband is a commercial driver in the Bibiani Township.

Felicia enjoys trading very much. She owns a provision shop in which she sells groceries such as milk, milo, sugar, biscuits, bread as well as other food items. She has been in business for five years. Felicia also sells minerals such as Coca-Cola and Fanta. She says that she procures most of her goods from the big cities nearby.

Felicia is in the process of expanding her business. She has acquired a bigger store by the main road where she hopes to make very good sales. Felicia wants to use the loan to complete work on the new shop and also procure goods in large quantities to stock both shops. She hopes to run the two shops concurrently by seeking a helping hand. She is in the Genesis Trust Bank group. The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To complete work on her shop and procure groceries in bulk.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama K. is thirty-eight years old and married with four children. She has a boy who helps her with her house chores. The first three of her children are in the basic school. The last is currently just crawling. She lives with the family in a mining and farming dominated town called Bibiani in the Western Region.

Ama enjoys trading very much. She owns a provision shop in which she sells groceries such as milk, milo, sugar, and biscuits. She also sells vegetables on a table top in front of her shop, which is on the street. She sells the vegetables mostly to the people in her community who usually walk all the way to the market to buy them. She has been in business for five years.

Ama says that she buys some of the goods, especially the vegetables, from the small towns nearby. She travels to the bigger towns, however, to procure her groceries. She hopes to increase the quantity of goods that she buys at each trip so as to cut down on her frequent transportation and be able to sell to many people in her neighborhood and even beyond. She is in a group called Nyame Nhyira (God’s Blessings). The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy provision and vegetables in bulk to sell in her store.

loans.name: Alma Lola

texts.es:
La señora Alma Lola Beltrán H. tiene 37 años, es tesorera del Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en  Mz I lote 24 del Asentamiento Humano Luis Alberto Sánchez del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry de la provincia de Trujillo departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió educación secundaria y empezó a estudiar Comunicaciones pero no concluyó porque se casó y tiene 2 hijos que aun son estudiantes.
Alma es cosmetóloga y también vende cena en las noches o comidas al paso, actividad que realiza en su casa.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que canceló en 4 cuotas, lo invirtió en comprar un espejo y una vitrina.
Con este crédito de 1400 que será cancelado en 6 cuotas invertirá en compra de juguetes y  arreglar un ambiente para sus ventas de comidas.
Alma sueña con comprarse un carro.
texts.en:
Alma Lola Beltrán H. is 37 years old and treasurer of the “Enterprising Women II” cooperative bank. She lives in the Trujillo province, located in La Libertad, Perú. She completed secondary school and began studies in Communications, but did not finish because she got married and had two children who are still students. Alma is in cosmetology, and also sells dinners at night or food to go, activities that she conducts from her home. With her first loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles, which she repaid in four installments, she invested in the purchase of a mirror and display cabinet. With this loan of 1,400.00 Peruvian soles, to be repaid in six installments, she will invest in the purchase of toys and improve the ambiance for her food sales. Alma dreams of buying her own car.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase toys for the holiday season.  To make improvements to her location.

loans.name: Betty Marleny

texts.es:
L. señora Betty Marleny L. C.  A. tiene 48 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II  y vive en L. Avenida Petro Perú  Mz F lote 9 del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry de L. provincia de Trujillo del departamento de L. Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta primer año de secundaria, pero no continuo estudiando por falta de apoyo económico. Se comprometió con su pareja desde L. edad de 17 años y tiene 5 hijos, de los cuales uno depende de elL. económicamente.
Su negocio por lo general es de venta de ropa pero actualmente cambio su negocio por venta de panetones de casa en casa por L. época de Navidad.
El primer crédito fue de 300 soles que canceló en 4 cuotas, con el cual compró ropa y zapatos, manifiesta que fue de gran provecho.
Con este crédito de 300 que será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará panetones, porque ya le quedan muy pocos, dice.
Betty toda L. vida soñó con tener una gran tienda.
texts.en:
Betty Marleny L. C. A. is 48 years old and belongs to Enterprising Women II coooperative bank. She lives in the Trujillo province, located in L. Libertad, Perú. She completed her studies up to the first year of secondary school, but did not continue due to lack of financial resources. She became engaged at the age of 17 and has since had five children, two of whom still depend on her support. Her business involves clothing sales, however she has currently switched to selling panetones (a traditional holiday cake with raisins and dried fruits) door-to-door because of the Christmas season. With her first loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles, which she paid in four installments, she bought clothes and shoes and she tells us that this was very helpful. With this loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles to be repaid in four installments she will purchase panetones since, she tells us, her supply is low. Betty has dreamed her whole life of having a grand store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase panetones (a traditional holiday cake with raisins and dried fruit).

loans.name: Candy Selene

texts.es:
La señora Candy Selene S. F. tiene 27 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en la calle Pasaje La Marina 606 del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry de la provincia de Trujillo departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió Enfermería Técnica, pero no termino porque se comprometió con su pareja a los 17 años. Tiene 2 hijos que aun son estudiantes.
Candy se dedica a la venta de muñecos de Peluche, marcianos y otros, lo realiza en su casa.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles cancelados en 4 cuotas, que  invirtió en compra de productos de belleza que en ese tiempo vendía.
Con este crédito de 1000 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas, lo invertirá en su negocio.
Candy desea con ver a sus hijos profesionales y con un gran futuro.
texts.en:
Candy Selene S. F. is 27 years old and belongs to the “Enterprising Women II” cooperative bank. She lives in the Trujillo province, located in La Libertad, Perú. She studied Nursing, but did not finish because she became engaged at the age of 17. She has two children who are still in school. Candy dedicates herself to selling stuffed toys/dolls from her home. With her first loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles, which she paid in four installments, she invested in the purchase of the beauty products she sold at that time. With this loan of 1,000.00 Peruvian soles, to be repaid in six installments, she will invest in her business. Candy’s wish is to see her children become professionals with bright futures.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her business.

loans.name: Edith Gerelda

texts.es:
La señora Edith Gerelda Z. Ucañán tiene 34 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en la calle La Mar 649 del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry en la provincia de Trujillo, en el departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa e hizo cursos de alta costura, se casó y tiene 2 hijos que dependen de ella.
Su negocio consiste en venta de pescado en el mercado Los Luchadores, en sus horas libres, arregla vestidos, faldas, etc. También hace manualidades.
Su primer crédito fue de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas que los invirtió en su negocio de pescado.
Con este crédito de 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas invertirá en pescado.
Edith sueña con tener su casa y un negocio en la misma, para poder estar más tiempo con sus hijos.
texts.en:
Edith Gerelda Z. Ucañán is 34 years old and belongs to the “Enterprising Women II” cooperative bank. She lives in the Trujillo province, located in La Libertad, Perú. She completed secondary school and took courses in advanced sewing. She then married and has two children who now live on their own. Her business consists of selling seafood at the Los Luchadores market. In her free time, she tailors dresses, skirts, etc., and also makes handmade items. She invested her first loan of 300.00 Peruvian soles, which she repaid in four installments, into her seafood business. With this loan of 500.00 Peruvian soles, to be repaid in four installments, she will buy fish. Edith dreams of owning her own home where she can locate her business, and of spending more time with her children.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her seafood business.

loans.name: Emilia Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Emilia Rosa C. Esquén, tiene 43 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II, vive en la Avenida La Marina Mz lote 22 Aurora Díaz I del Puerto Marítimo Salaverry de la provincia de Trujillo,  departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió Enfermería Técnica y se casó de 25 años y tiene 2 hijos que aun son estudiantes.
Emilia vende productos de belleza de Unique y Ésika, en su casa y por pedido.
El primer crédito fue de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas y los invirtió en productos que se encontraban en oferta.
Con este crédito de 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas invertirá en productos de belleza para poder alcanzar stock.
Emilia sueña con tener su propia empresa.
texts.en:
Mrs. Emilia Rosa C. Esquén is 43 years old and belongs to the Community Bank "Las Emprendedoras II" (The Enterprising Women II). She lives on La Marina Avenue, lot 22 Aurora Diaz I of the Salaverry Port in the province of Trujillo, in the state of La Libertad, in Peru. She studied nursing and was married at 25. She has two children who are still students. Emilia sells beauty products from Unique and Esika, in her home and through orders. Her first loan for 300 soles was paid in 4 payments. She invested it in products that were on sale. With this loan of 500 soles, which will be repaid in 5 payments, she will invest in beauty products to increase her stock. Emilia dreams of having her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beauty products to sell

loans.name: Ismelda Edita

texts.es:
La señora Ismelda Edita L. Venegas tiene 48 años,  pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive  en la Avenida La Marina Mz 1 lote 18 Aurora Díaz I del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta segundo año de secundaria, pero no continuó estudiando por motivos económicos, pero se capacitó como cosmetóloga. Se casó de 25 años y tiene 6 hijos de los cuales 5 son estudiantes.
Tiene un pequeño salón de belleza  que funciona en su casa.
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas compró insumos para su salón.
Con este crédito de 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas invertirá en productos para su negocio como, navajas, champú, tintes.
Ismelda sueña con tener un salón muy grande.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ismelda Edita L. Venegas is 48 years old and belongs to the Community Bank "Las Emprendedoras II" (The Enterprising Women II). She lives on La Marina Mz 1 Avenue, Lot 18, Aurora Diaz 1 of the Salaverry Port in the province of Trujillo, in the state of La Libertad, Peru. She studied through her second year of middle school but did not continue studying due to economic reasons. However, she trained herself as a cosmetologist. She was married at 25 and has 6 children, 5 of whom are students. She has a small beauty salon that she runs out of her home. With her first loan credit of 300 soles, paid in 4 payments, she bought supplies for her salon. With this loan of 500 soles, which will be paid in 4 payments, she will invest in products for her business, such as razors, shampoo and hair dye. Ismelda dreams of having a large salon.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase products for her business such as razors, shampoo and hair dye

loans.name: Irma Nidia

texts.es:
La señora Irma Nidia M. B. tiene 70 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en la calle Trujillo 636 del Puerto Marítimo Salaverry de la provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa y se caso a los 20 años, tiene 4 hijos y una hija que es su socia en su negocio. Todos sus hijos están casados.
Irma se dedica a confeccionar peluches, bolsas para regalitos de cumpleaños, piñatas, etc., de acuerdo a los pedidos que le hagan, lo realiza en su casa.
El primer crédito fue de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas, con lo que compró material para confeccionar peluches.
Con este crédito de 1200 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas comprará material para la temporada de Navidad.
Irma desea de todo corazón tener una fábrica de peluches y artesanía.
texts.en:
Mrs. Irma Nidia M. B. is 70 years old and belongs to the Community Bank "Las Emprendedoras II" (The Enterprising Women II). She lives at 636 Trujillo Street in the Salaverry Port, in the province of Trujillo, in the state of La Libertad, Peru. She completed secondary school and got married when she was 20 years old. She has 4 sons and a daughter, who is her business partner. All of her children are married. Irma works making stuffed animals, gift bags, piñatas, etc. She completes the orders people give her from her home. Her first loan of 300 soles was canceled in 4 payments. She used it to buy material to make stuffed animals. With this loan of 1200 soles, which will be repaid in 6 payments, she will buy material for the holiday season. Irma wishes with all of her heart to have an arts and crafts factory.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material for the holiday season

loans.name: Juana Miriam

texts.es:
L. señora Juana Miriam G. D. D. L. C., tiene 55 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en L. calle L. Marina 634 del Puerto Marítimo  D. Salaverry provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. L. Libertad Perú.
Estudió hasta quinto año D. primaria, no continuó estudiando debido a L. falta D. recursos económicos. Se casó D. 14 años,  tuvo 10 hijos, dos D. ellos murieron, ahora dependen D. elL. 3 jóvenes estudiantes.
VenD. cerveza y golosinas en su casa, siempre realizó ese trabajo.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas, compró armarios para exponer sus golosinas.
Con este crédito D. 800 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas, invertirá en cerveza.
Juana sueña con tener una tienda granD..
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana Miriam G. D. L. C. is 55 years old and belongs to the Enterprising Women II Communal Bank. She lives at 634 Marina Street in the seaport of Salaverry, in the province of Trujillo, department of L. Libertad, Peru. She studied until fifth graD. but then did not continue studying because she didn’t have the money. She married at 14 years old and had 10 children, two of whom died, and now three of her children are dependent on her and are students. She sells beer and sweets from her home, which she has always done. With the first loan of 300 soles ($100), which she repaid in 4 months, she bought cabinets to display her sweets. With this loan of 800 soles ($275), which she will repay over 6 months, she will buy beer. Juana dreams of having a big store.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beer to sell in her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase of raw materials for their dyeing business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase of raw materials for dyeing cloth

loans.name: Julia Gliceria

texts.es:
La señora Julia Gliceria P. M.  tiene 50 años , pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II  y vive en la calle Lambayeque 529 del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió Biología en la Universidad Nacional pero trabaja como profesora de la especialidad dictando algunas horas en un pequeño colegio particular, cuyo sueldo no le alcanza para vivir por lo que tiene que dedicarse a otras actividades.
Se casó a los 32 años y tiene una hija de 15 años, que es estudiante.
Julia hace hermosos muñecos de peluche, también hace billuteria (aretes, pulseras, cadenas) el material lo compra en Trujillo o Lima, esta actividad la realiza en su casa.
Con este crédito de 300 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas, invertirá en material para peluches de Navidad.
Julia sueña con poner una fábrica propia de peluches y billuteria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Julia Gliceria P. M. is 50 years old and belongs to the Enterprising Women II Communal Bank. She lives at 529 Lambayeque Street in the seaport of Salaverry, province of Trujillo and department of La Libertad, Peru. She studied biology at the national university but works as a biology teacher at a small private high school. Her salary is not enough to cover her living expenses, so she has to also do other activities. She married at 32 years old and has a 15-year old daughter who is a student. Julia makes beautiful stuffed animals as well as jewelry (earrings, bracelets and chains) from materials she buys in Trujillo or Lima. She works from her home. With this loan of 300 soles ($100), which she will repay over 4 months, she will invest in material for Christmas stuffed animals. Julia dreams of having her own factory for her stuffed animals and jewelry.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy material for Christmas-themed stuffed animals

loans.name: Liza Marie

texts.es:
La señora Liza Marie E. Ramírez tiene 28 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en la calle Trujillo 673 del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry en la provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió educación secundaria completa, ya no continuó estudiando porque se casó y tiene un hijo y una hija que aun son pequeños.
Su negocio consiste en venta de comida en sociedad con su abuela en un restaurant que se ubica en la calle Libertad 579.
El primer crédito fue de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas el cual lo invirtió en bebidas; gaseosa y cerveza.
Con este crédito de 1400 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas lo invertirá en; arroz, azúcar, aceite y otros insumos para el restaurant.
Liza sueña con tener su negocio propio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Liza Marie E. Ramírez is 28 years old and belongs to the Enterprising Women II Communal Bank. She lives at 673 Trujillo Street in the seaport of Salaverry, Trujillo province, department of La Libertad, Peru. She completed high school but did not continue her education after that because she married and has a son and a daughter who are still young. Her business is selling food in partnership with her grandmother in a restaurant located at 579 Libertad Street. The first loan of 300 soles, which she repaid over 4 months, was used to buy beverages (soft drinks and beer). This loan of 1,400 soles ($475), which will be repaid over 6 months, will be used to buy rice, sugar, oil, and other ingredients for her restaurant. Liza dreams of having her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, oil and other ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Manuela Candelaria

texts.es:
La señora Manuela Candelaria H. D. V. tiene 52 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II  y vive en la calle La Mar 162 del Puerto Marítimo D. Salaverry en la provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa y es cosmetóloga, se casó a los 27 años, tiene 3 hijos los cuales son estudiantes.
Manuela tiene un salón D. belleza en la calle Gonzales Prada  360 en la ciudad D. Trujillo y se llama Estética Manuelita, sus clientas siempre están muy a gusto con ella porque a parte D. ser muy amable con ellas realiza excelentes trabajos.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas, lo invirtió en insumos para el salón.
Con esté crédito D. 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas invertirá en nuevos productos para su stock.
Manuela sueña con tener un salón granD. y en un lugar más céntrico.
texts.en:
Mrs. Manuela Calendaria H. D. V. is 52 years old and belongs to the Enterprising Women II Communal Bank. She lives at 162 La Mar Street in the seaport of Salaverry, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Peru. She completed high school and is a cosmetologist. She married at 27 years old and has 3 children who are students. Manuela has a beauty salon called Esthetic Manuelita at 360 Gonzales Prada Street in Trujillo. Her clients like her very much because besides being very friendly, she also does great work. With her first loan of 300 soles ($100), which she repaid over 4 months, she bought supplies for the salon. With this loan of 500 soles ($175), which she will repay over 4 months, she will buy more products for her salon. Manuela dreams of having a larger salon that is more conveniently located.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more products for her salon

loans.name: Margarita Asuncion Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Margarita Asunción del Carmen A. F., tiene 37 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II y vive en el Asentamiento Humano Miguel Grau Mz  C lote 23 del Puerto Marítimo de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa y complementó sus estudios con el aprendizaje de Corte y Confección. Manifiesta que gracias al Movimiento Manuela Ramos aprendió Maquillaje, pedicure y manicure que le enseñaron en un bonito taller.
De su primer compromiso matrimonial tiene 3 hijos, y del segundo compromiso tiene una hija, los cuales todavía son estudiantes.
Margarita atiende un Wawa Wasi y lo hace con mucho cariño y dedicación, pero como es una mujer emprendedora, también se dedica al reciclaje de plástico, lata, papel, bronce, cobre. El Wawa Wasi lo atiende en su casa y el depósito de reciclaje lo tiene en un corralón del costado de su casa.
El primer crédito de 300 soles cancelado en 4 cuotas, invirtió 150 soles para reciclaje y con los otros 150 compró pañales para venderlos en el Wawa Wasi a las madres que deseaban.
Con este crédito de 800 soles que será cancelado en 6 cuotas invertirá en reciclaje.
texts.en:
Mrs. Margarita Asunción del Carmen A. F. is 37 years old and belongs to the Communal Bank of Entrepreneurs II (Banco Comunal Las Emprendedoras II). She lives in the Miguel Grau Mz C Settlement, lot 23 of the Maritime Port of Salaverry, Province of Trujillo, District of La Libertad Perú.
